section.title: Description
section.para: Use this view to enter pattern data. Since Neil is a so-called tracker, you have to enter notes in a certain quite peculiar format. Time in trackers go from top to bottom. Each line in this view is a musical event. Columns are used to enter data which are always integral numbers displayed in hexadecimal. These numbers can be used to set synthesizer parameters, note values and other performance data.

section.title: Editting patterns
section.para: An example of a 16 bar pattern is shown bellow. It is for the Oomek Aggressor machine. Oomek Aggressor is a an emulator of a famous bassline synthesizer by a famous Japanese company. It comes with the standard Neil machine set and it has very many musical applications starting with obvious basslines and acid leads and ending with sound effects and all even pads. If you need examples of good use for this kind of synthesizer just check out old Plastikman records. To see how you add this machine to your song read the manual page on using the Router view. This assumes that you have added the machine and have the first pattern open in the pattern editor. Obviously, when you open that view it won't contain the pattern below. This is just a pattern I entered semi-randomly.

You can see that the view is divided in to two big columns. The first one contains global parameters and the other one contains track parameters. A particular machine can ommit one or both of these. Global parameters usually control the sound of the synth. It is used to enter values that would affect, for example, cutoff frequency of a synthesizers filter. As a matter of fact this one does contain a column for that. You use the arrow keys to move around in the pattern view editor. Click with the mouse on the view if it is not in focus and try using the arrow keys to move the cursor. As you move the cursor notice that a short description of the column you are on appears below the pattern editor. For example, try locating the cutoff frequency and resonance in the global parameter column.

Values are entered using a hexadecimal base format. This used to be done because it allows to enter values that fit in to one byte using just two digits. Similarly it allows to enter two bytes using four digits. It has to do with the way that computers store information. While it requires to think a little differently it is a compact way of entering numeric information in to computers. To convert from hexadecimal to decimal you can use the two formulas below. They are for the two and four digit cases respectively. Neil only allows those two types numeric values.

section.title: Navigating with keyboard
section.para: For those of you who prefer using keyboard to using mouse (this is probably everyone when shown how). Apart from moving the cursor with arrow keys there are ways to change the active machine, pattern, wave, step, octave and to make selections in the pattern editor. To change the active machine use Ctrl + Up and Ctrl + Down shortcut. To change the active pattern use "+" and "-" keys on the numeric keypad if your are on a laptop use the key kombination that emulates numeric keypad. Plus key increases active pattern number while the minus key decreases it. To change the active wave you can use the "<" and ">" keys. Use the "*" and "/" keys on the numpad to change the active octave up and down one octave. Use the "[" and "]" keys to change the step size for the editor. To manage selections with the keyboard just hold down the "Shift" button and use the arrow keys to select. When you want to deselect, release the "Shift" key and use the arrow keys to move the cursor.
